caption: Here today visiting for the Chantal Ackerman Exhibition, which was excellent. Interesting to see the films reworked in a different way. Fascinating to also see the texts, documents & early shorts.
Their exhibitions show top-notch photo and moving image art.

The first time I came here, I went to see a movie in the basement and was surprised why there was a museum here that I didn't know so I went back again.  This time I came for the Thomas Demand exhibition.  You can buy tickets inside the museum (buy directly with the staff or buy on the machine).  You can also make an appointment in advance.  I see this as more of a gallery than a museum, also not too crowded so it is very quiet.
Beautiful photo exhibit !

Nice sized arts centre (I did not take photos of the actual exhibition). It‚Äôs two floors and well conceived. The area around is very nice to walk around and enjoy a view of the Eiffel Tower and other Parisian attractions.

The space itself isn't that extraordinary to look at from the outside but read up on the fascinating history. I visited the Sally Mann show which was wonderful. The galleries are a bit compact so try and go early or late to avoid the crowds. Nice bookstore too and when the weather is good, the cafe outside is nice.
Amazing photography gallery. It‚Äôs open ‚Äòtil 9pm on a Tuesday. Which leaves you enough time to watch the sunset over Place de Concord in the summer ‚òÄÔ∏èüåá
One of my favorite little museums in Paris, especially if you like photography. Exhibits aren‚Äôt always photography but often enough.

It is a magnificent building. During my stay in Paris, there was a photography exhibition by Frank Horvat. He was a photographer who lived and worked in France. He is best known for his fashion photography. Horvat's oeuvre includes a very wide range of photographs.

I'm afraid I done much like the style of monochrome photography now featured in the exhibits. However, it is a great venue and others may like the darkish themes. The cafe is well-done Japanese... strangely appropriate.

Consistantly amazing shows, especially well curated exhibitions beautifully showcased around the time of Paris Photo. I have yet to see a less than impactful, unique, beautifully executed exhibition there in all these years.
I was visiting for a Chantal Akerman exhibition which was curated pretty nicely, I really enjoyed it, good work
Wonderfully designed interior to a classic building. The exhibition on Demand (the photographer not the verb) was fascinating.
My favourite art gallery because it always promotes female photographers. Don‚Äôt go if you don‚Äôt like art or females.
Amazing view to the tower, easy to access, no line and beautiful lights during the day!
They denied me entry because the lady refused to look at my ticket. They accused me of buying a ticket for the previous day even though it clearly said for THAT DAY!
Paris - An interesting gallery. Went to see the Howat Exhibition. Contemporary art book shop. Worth a visit check on line for current exhibitions.
Great location in the heart of Jardin des Tuileries to see new picture exhibitions
A place to be to explore photography. Again, a great experience. Cant wait to visit again
Great museum, great terrasse spot in the sun with fantastic Japanese food

EXPO SALLY MANN +++ THE PAINS OF THE SOUTH ++ EMMETT FLOATING ++ COLLODIUM ++ GO AND SEE ++ AN ANGEL FOR SALLY MANN  Certainly, Jeu de Paume is one of the finest places in Europe to see expositions of photograph artists. So, Josef Sudek, or Andr√© Kertesz some time ago. The current Expo of Sally Mann is - convincingly - of very radical nature. Starting with the early pictures of her three children , amounting today to a kind of miracle, Sally Mann took always a lot of "insight" on her. The expo is cut in five "subject-parts", and one of the most fascinating are the so called "Black Water" pictures,  really "tirages" in the old French style. Or, other subject (matter), the battlefields of the South, rough, but wonderful. And then the Little Videos, shown at the expo, Sally Mann with grey hair (she is born in 1951). Collodium Floating on glass plates. This is not an "easy go", but 90 minutes at the expo will comfort you a lot. It took me six hours (each time) by train to come and to go, but is was quite a unique occasion (as Josef Sudek earlier). And Sally Mann, also, is a very interesting example that there is a withhold against the simply "loudspeaking world". Subtle Pictures of the South ! Congratulation ! After the visit, I was talking to a lot of interested People, in photography. How to sustain "pain" is one of the most fundamental subjects you can Encounter, and Sally Mann did very well, also at Jeu de Paume ! Go and see the "Black Water" Pictures, and the Battlefields. What an achievement, very honest, South !

Only went in because I'd time to kill before meeting family but it was excellent. Main exhibition space is wonderful, the Stutter of History exhibition is so good. Staff throughout are friendly and helpful, cafe is good, and there's a well-stocked bookshop. Recommended

Extremely well-organized temporary exhibitions on 2 floors. I visited several museums around this time in Paris and I must say the air-conditioning was the best here - not an unimportant value in 35¬∞C. Staff is very kind too.
Nice museum, not too crowded even on the weekends. I visit regularly and never had to book tickets.

Jeu de Paume is a museum located in the Tuileries Garden in Paris, France. The museum is dedicated to photography and contemporary art, with a focus on showcasing experimental and innovative works.  Originally built as a tennis court in the 17th century, the building was later converted into an exhibition space in the 20th century. Today, it serves as a platform for contemporary artists to display their works, particularly in the medium of photography.  The Jeu de Paume museum hosts temporary exhibitions that explore various themes and artistic practices. It features a diverse range of photography, video art, and other forms of contemporary visual arts. The museum often collaborates with international artists and curators, making it a dynamic and engaging cultural institution.  In addition to exhibitions, Jeu de Paume offers educational programs, workshops, and lectures to promote a deeper understanding and appreciation of contemporary art. It also maintains an extensive library and archive, providing resources for researchers, scholars, and art enthusiasts.  Jeu de Paume is a unique and vibrant museum that contributes to the rich cultural landscape of Paris. Its location in the Tuileries Garden makes it easily accessible and offers visitors the opportunity to combine their visit with a leisurely stroll through the beautiful garden.  If you have an interest in contemporary art, photography, or experimental visual arts, a visit to Jeu de Paume is highly recommended. It provides a platform for emerging and established artists to showcase their works and offers a thought-provoking and immersive experience for visitors.

Fantastic photography museum. Exhibitions are always interesting and the program mixes big names in the field & young masters on the rise. The building is very nice, keeping a human-scale size that makes it nice to me. And the library is full of great books...
Their expositions are so beautifully curated also it's such a perfect spot in Jardin Tuileries while on your walk in the gardens you could simply stop by the mus√©e for some lovely expos!
Very beautiful place and great exhibitions, friendly staff

Small. But extremely interesting. Not crowded. Very contemporary and relevant to today's life. Opposite of the Louvre - quite tiny, but you will not see this content in art history books, or anywhere else!
I had a great time being enthralled with art. I've also been very inspired
Ideally located at the Concorde Tuileries garden entrance, a nice cultural pit stop for exhibitions and savory lunch or coffee break at Rose Bakery within the premises.

Yesterday me and my friend tried to go into the museum, he had his travel backpack with him as he was leaving Paris that evening. As we entered the building, the girl at the entrance was already very grumpy. She didn't speak a word in English although my friend told her that he doesn't understand a word in French. Then she told us to put his backpack in one of the safes, which obviously were way to small. So when we bought our tickets we asked if we could take the bag inside, the man already said yes, but then this girl from the entrance came running up to us, and told us, again in a very unfriendly way that it was not possible to take it inside.  Today I visited the museum. I am a big fan of photography, but for the price the collection is very poor. And really not that spectacular. The short films in the top floor are nice, but again really not worth the price.  Fun fact: In the area with the computers are two big safes for baggage that you can lock, and my friend's bag would've definitely fit in there.  Imma just say: where there's a will, there's a way.
A superb gallery showing modern art, in this case the photography of Julia Margaret Cameron from the 1860s.

It is a very good gallery. On the first floor you can find a really cool book shop with photo albums from different collections. I also like the cafe, there you can find some very nice japonese food and deserts, which I really liked.  I highly reccommend this place.)

While it's an obvious place to go (in every guide book), take care to note what specifically is on display there. I went without noticing the exhibits' details and didn't particularly care for them. Nothing bad about them, but also no standing collection to fall back upon.
Outstanding gallery space and consistently good curation of exhibits. The size of the galleries makes for a nicely paced visit. There is a Japanese cafe on-site, which was good for a snack.
One of my favourite museums in Paris. There is usually a really well curated photography exhibition and sometimes also video... the location is super nice too.
The interior is bright. Two large rooms on two floors. Toilets are clean, you can even drop its stuffs in traps code. Provision of informational screens with headphones. Very nice place
